posts.name: James
posts.cooked: Does anyone have any guides or resources that can help learn how to wire an elevator? I understand the basic information about FIRST Robotics Competition electrical but I'm looking for specifics on wiring an elevator.

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked: Wiring an elevator requires addressing two potential scenarios: either wiring the drive motor(s) situated at the base of the elevator or establishing wiring from the top to the elevator's highest point. For the former case, standard wiring techniques applicable to the motor located on the robot's base are utilized. Conversely, when wiring to the top, one must extend the wiring to the maximum height of the elevator and slightly exceed this length. This involves bundling all the necessary wire into a cable track to ensure protection and securing it to reach the top of the first stage of the elevator. Apart from these specific wiring adjustments, the rest of the wiring setup remains consistent with other components on the robot.

posts.name: George Horsey
posts.cooked: Running in a cable track is recommended, especially for its durability. Plan ahead by determining the number of wires needed and the space they occupy before purchasing cable track. The feed-through type is more reliable but can be problematic if slightly too small, necessitating careful measurement beforehand. Consider using a separate smaller cable track for sensor wiring, though combining power and sensor cabling has worked well in the past. To enhance redundancy, create a dedicated CAN bus section specifically for communication between controllers, ensuring continuity even if a wire fails in the cable track. Always label both ends of every wire before inserting it into the track. Secure the cable track firmly and plan for strain relief on both ends. Move everything manually at a slow pace, avoiding pinching or kinks. For rotating joints, route wires near the pivot to prevent damage. Use a plastic wire loom if space is constrained around a pivot, yet still protect the wire’s insulation.

posts.name: Kyle
posts.cooked: My team is experiencing difficulty with the cable track swinging during driving. Is there a guide available for the cable track so that it sits properly?

posts.name: George Horsey
posts.cooked: Multiple shorter lengths and polycarbonate guides are what we do to prevent the swinging.

posts.name: T.Krauter
posts.cooked:
For electronics on an extension, we use spring spiral wire. This season and in 2023, they worked quite well. Larger sizes provide power to bigger electronics, along with Ethernet cables running CAN signals and lower voltages. Heavier, but the reliability is worth it.

The 2025 robot uses specific wires, while the 2023 version had similar components.

posts.name: Everett33
posts.cooked: Use a larger track than needed. Smaller tracks have thinner plastic walls that allow links to bend and potentially separate, especially with high-speed movement. They don’t handle the high momentum from swerve drives properly when placed sideways; instead, align the U-shaped track with the robot’s usual movement direction. Smaller tracks are affected by the cables inside, causing them to bend unexpectedly due to the cables returning to their normal position after being bent. Larger bend radius tracks reduce this wear. Use polycarbonate or tensioning devices to guide the chain away from hazards. Some chains, like the E-Z chain, allow adding or removing cables from the outside of the bend. Twisting wires can cause damage or short circuits. Efficiently use a single chain run by positioning the fixed end higher and the moving part lower on the carriage, such as with a 60-inch travel setup.
